Element 14: Management Review and Metrics. The intent of this element is to ensure a clear line of sight of relevant performance indicators at appropriate levels in the organization. These are used to identify system improvement opportunities and to provide early indication of pending failures of systems designed to prevent a major incident event from occurring. Leading and lagging metrics are established at appropriate levels of the organization to measure PSM system effectiveness and impact and executive and management forums at appropriate levels of the organization regularly receive and review reports regarding effectiveness and impact of PSM systems, and act on system and performance improvement opportunities and react to emerging or existing system deficiencies.

Element 15: Audit and Continuous Improvement. The intent of this element is to provide assurance that relevant parts of the organization are meeting the performance requirements of the Process Safety Management Standard, to identify trends, and to act on improvement opportunities. The facility conducts an annual PSM audit self-assessment of the site health, safety, and environment (HSE) management systems to establish the extent of compliance with each relevant element and performance requirement of the standard. Corporate audits are conducted biennially to establish the extent of compliance with the standard, and triennial compliance audits are conducted to verify that the procedures and practices d

eveloped under the PSM Standard and RMP Rule are adequate and are being followed. Performance improvement plans are prepared and executed to address non-conformances following each audit.

The facility has implemented Process Safety and Risk Management (PSRM) procedures to address the requirements the Nufarm Corporate Process Safety Management Standard, OSHA PSM Standard and the EPA RMP Rule.

Element 10: Emergency Planning and Response. The intent of this element is to mitigate the impact and losses arising from incidents. The facility emergency response plan establishes resources and ensure operational readiness that includes trained and equipped emergency response teams. The facility also prepares Pre-Incident Plans (PIPs) for each emergency scenario that is defined as a major incident.

Element 11: Contractor & Third-Party Safety Management. The intent of this element is to ensure that the contracting of services, or the purchase, hire or lease of equipment, materials, and activities are carried out so as to eliminate adverse PSM consequences. This includes a pre-qualification selection process prior to contract to ensure the contractors PSM experience and performance meets the relevant performance requirements of the standard and that systems are implemented that ensure the PSM performance of suppliers, contractors and partners, where relevant.

Element 12: Incident Reporting & Management. The intent of this element is to ensure that PSM related incidents are reported, investigated and analyzed and that corrective and preventative actions are taken, and lessons shared. It established processes for the timely reporting, investigation, mitigation and appropriate communication and escalation to senior management of all PSM related incidents such as loss of containment. The processes also addresses the identification and documentation of all the factors and underlying root causes that contributed to an incident, the controls that were intended to prevent it, and analysis of any failures in the controls.

Element 6: Hazardous Materials Management. The intent of this element is to eliminate or minimize the risk of fatalities, illnesses and incidents arising from the storage, handling, processing, production, transport, recycling and disposal of hazardous materials. This element addresses requirements and security and access control to covered process areas and prevention of introduction of ignition sources around flammable materials. This element also addresses Hazard Communication and process safety information pertaining to the hazards of the highly hazardous chemicals used by the covered processes.

Element 7: Asset Integrity Management. The intent of this element is to ensure that PSM Assets continue to perform their required function and continue to maintain design intent so as to prevent, control and mitigate unexpected losses of containment that could result in a major incident event. The facility uses the HIRAC process and other appropriate means to identify relevant process equipment and controls for inclusion in the PSM Asset [Mechanical] Integrity Management (AIM) program and the AIM program to establish, document, and maintain processes and systems to ensure the ongoing integrity of PSM Assets.

Element 8: Management of Change. The intent of this element is to ensure the ongoing safe conduct of manufacturing, any proposed changes in operations, procedures, facilities, critical personnel or organizational structures shall be evaluated, authorized and managed to ensure that risks arising from these changes remain at an acceptable level. 

Element 9: Isolation & Permit to Work. The intent of this element is to ensure that occupational safety, environmental, and process safety risk is maintained at an acceptable level when conducting maintenance or unusual operations on plant and equipment. A documented Permit to Work (PTW) process is implemented to identify hazards and assess risk and to identi

ent, operations, facilities layout and maintenance undergo an appropriate level of assessment to identify risk and appropriate layers of risk controls. The overarching principle to apply is that the hazard assessment methodology, layers of risk controls and documentation shall be appropriate to and commensurate with the complexity, type, likelihood of occurrence and potential consequence of the hazard. The facility has implemented a formal, documented hazard analysis, risk assessment and control process using appropriate qualitative and quantitative process hazard analysis (PHA) methodologies.

Element 4: Facility Design & Construction. The intent of this element is to ensure that management of PSM risk and improvement objectives is an integral part of all projects through design, approval, procurement, construction, commissioning and decommissioning. This element addresses technical standards of design, construction and commissioning requirements and includes Pre-Startup Safety Reviews for newly installed and modified process areas and equipment to confirm that construction is in accordance with design codes and standards, actions identified through the HIRAC (PHA) process, and that all required verifications are complete.

Element 5: Operations Safety. The intent of this element is to ensure that all PSM Assets are operated according to the risk control requirements arising from the HIRAC for that plant. This includes written procedures for operating PSM Assets and that the procedures include risk control aspects identified through the HIRAC process that address the operating phases of the equipment (e.g., normal start-up, normal operation, normal shutdown, etc.), and potential consequences of deviation from operating limits, and control measures to keep within operating limits and steps to manage and correct deviations from those limits. Element 1: Leadership & Accountability. The intent of this element is to ensure that Nufarm managers, employees and contractors understand their PSM accountabilities and demonstrate leadership and commitment to PSM. This includes training in PSM principles, systems and processes to enable managers to recognize potential PSM implications in business decisions and business performance and ensuring that systems for PSM are established and ensuring the systems are sufficiently communicated, deployed, maintained and supported. This element also addresses planning and resources for effective implementation and operation of PSM management processes and systems and ensuring experienced and competent staff are made available to oversee and effectively deploy PSM management programs at manufacturing sites. Managers are accountable for ensuring PSM risk and performance is assessed in areas of their business and to act for improvement where indicated.

Element 2: Training and Competence. The intent of this element is to ensure that employees and visitors are aware of relevant PSM hazards, risks and controls and are trained and competent to safely conduct their PSM related activities. The facility has identified relevant competency-based training needs that are critical to PSM and delivers that training to management, employees and contractors whose tasks and actions impact the process safety of the site operations. This training includes both PSM principles as well as procedure-specific training for those procedures that form part of the risk control layers of protection for specific PSM hazards at the site.

Nufarm Corporate HSE conducted a management system audit at this facility in November 2019 that included elements of the PSM/RMP program including Management of Change, Contractor Safety, Incident Reporting, and Mechanical (Asset) Integrity. The last two PSM/RMP compliance audits were conducted by separate third-parties in June 2021 and March 2022 to provide a comprehensive assessment of Nufarm’s PSM & RMP Program. Gap closure plan status is a key performance indicator (KPI) monitored under the PSM Deployment Metric in Nufarm’s Process Safety Metrics.

The facility has developed a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) and Layer of Protection Analysis (LOPA) procedure and the most recent PHA of the covered processes was conducted in September 2022. A facility siting study was conducted in 2020 and that study evaluated results and evacuations of possible events from a flammable cloud, jet fire, pool fire, and toxic cloud. Recommendation closure status is a key performance indicator (KPI) monitored under the PSM Deployment Metric in Nufarm’s Process Safety Metrics.

Planned changes to improve safety include interlocking Rail Unloading Station grounding verification control panels to shut down the unloading pumps and actuator valves if grounding assurance is not maintained. Nufarm has an on-going commitment to implement changes that will improve the safety of the employees and the community when opportunities for improvement are identified. Accordingly, Nufarm is actively engaged in addressing all recommendations identified in the most recent triennial compliance audits and process hazard analyses.

The facility has not experienced any accidental releases reportable under §68.42(a).

Nufarm Americas, Inc. (Nufarm) located in Chicago Heights, Illinois manufactures water-based herbicides using Dimethylamine (DMA) and Mono-Isopropylamine (MIPA) in the processes. MIPA and DMA are regulated substances under Section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act and are subject to the Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions of Part 68 under the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) Rule. These processes are also subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) process safety management (PSM) standard under 29 CFR 1910.119; thus, these processes are regulated as Program Level 3 processes.

MIPA and DMA are used in solution for glyphosate production. These regulated substances are delivered to the facility via rail cars and unloaded (transferred) to storage tanks located within a tank farm protected by an aqueous film forming foam (AFFF) fire suppression system. The substances are distributed to process reactors within the facility via process pumps and piping systems. The process reactors are connected to point of use process scrubbers.

Nufarm is committed to providing a safe, healthy and environmentally conscious workplace for its employees and community. Nufarm Corporate has established a Process Safety Management Standard to document and manage program elements under the chemical accident prevention provisions as required by EPA and OSHA. The Nufarm PSM Standard comprises 15 elements, each addressing a specific area of risk management and each of the elements describes the specific performance requirements for managing associated risk. Reference the Prevention Program section of this submittal for further information on the general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps.
